author: {'steamid': '76561198021255336', 'num_games_owned': 19, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 145, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 75, 'last_played': 1628619069}
review:
Boy do we have some poor design choices here (in no particular order).

General gameplay:

Individual weapons can overheat, but the meter is in the bottom right corner. Most of the time you'll be looking at your crosshair, so it would have been obvious to attach a heat meter to that.

If you do get the cursor to the edge of the screen, nearby HUD elements like the minimap become more transparent. This is actually a pretty good idea.

Your mech also has a stamina bar for sprinting and it must be fully depleted to recharge, which is okay I guess. Sadly you can't see the stamina bar unless you actually use the sprint button. You have to waste stamina to see how much you have left.

Because the camera is fixed, you'll always have a view distance advantage when moving north. Similarly you can hide behind large north facing cliffs. If an enemy tries to aim at you directly, their cursor will be on top of the cliff and all weapons will be aimed there.

Terrain doesn't convey clearly where you can move. Sometimes an impassable cliff is marked with a proper cliff texture, but not always. Sometimes it's the other way around and you can push up a cliff that looks impassable. Some destroyed buildings allow you to walk through them, others don't.

Enemies seem to be visible on the map most of the time, so don't think about sneaking anywhere or employing tactics. Just move towards the red icons and shoot. 

You can repair at your team's main spawn point, but there is no point in doing so. You're not helping the team while running back for 20 seconds and you don't even regain destroyed weapons. Just take the death, lose a ticket and get back into the fight.

Menu and stuff:

Language always resets to system default. It might say English in the options, but you still have to re-select it. Such a minor thing, but the German translation is cringe worthy and partially broken.

Weapons and upgrades need to be crafted and every crafted item has randomized rarity and stats. "Implants" can provide 2 out of a dozen different bonuses, so you'll be crafting a lot of them until you get what you want...or you pay money and buy lootboxes, because of course there are loot boxes.

Crafting is almost funny. If you want to compare a crafted item, you have to switch to the inventory. You can't set favorites, there are no filter options and the game doesn't even remember the last crafted item, so you have to look for it every single time. It's needlessly tedious.

Similarly bad the mech selection. You have to build a 'squad' by manually selecting each mech, but only from the same faction. If you wanna switch factions, uncheck all your current mechs first, then build a new squad...every time.
Does anybody remember how Heliborne did it? You create a new squad, fill it once, save it and just select the squad. 

TL:DR: Good enough for a mobile game that's fishing for whales, but rather mediocre on PC.

author: {'steamid': '76561198373917671', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 28, 'playtime_forever': 3843, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 78, 'last_played': 1651874216}
review:
UPDATED:

It's a top down, mecha combat game. I want to love it, but I just can't.
Great concept, bad implementation.

Poor grammar runs rampant within the game. Whether it is the tutorial instructions, description of items, even in the achievements.

Speaking of the tutorial, it's Broken. It will get to a certain point and then just stop, never to return again. I even tried it on another account with the same result. Although, unlike other reviews, I find that I can still play the game as normal despite it not working properly.

Controls are a bit clunky, as is the GUI.

Combat runs a bit slow, yet you can be instantly killed. In fact, you can be dead before you can even start playing, due to someone camping the spawn point, which you can barely even tell from the map. As a whole, the game is very unbalance and very much geared toward P2W & veterans players that have grinded it out (higher lvls equal better armor & damage).

The mechs themselves and the options available to customize them all look interesting, but the grind to get and build most of them are seemingly far beyond a casual gamer. And I certainly can't recommend anyone spending actual money on this in its current state. -Fortunately you can still collect a lot thru daily tasks and free loot crates provided by them; including mechs.

The game only has 2 (3 now) scenario modes. Team deathmatch and a 'king of the hill' type of base capture battle played on perhaps 4 different maps.  -Recently added a Capture the Flag mode (though no instructions are provided for new players to know what the goal is).

All this said, I will still continue to play this more as it does scratch that mecha itch that just isn't available elsewhere, despite the game's issues, namely because it is free.

And while playing for the Achievements is good, if a large grind, I have found that unfortunately even the some of the achievements are broken. Whether they popping literally every login after completing, or just never increasing.

author: {'steamid': '76561198354021776', 'num_games_owned': 134, 'num_reviews': 46, 'playtime_forever': 29, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 29, 'last_played': 1595587049}
review:
To summarise the game in one word: struggle.

Mechs don't move well and it feels like a struggle to get them into the right position, making me feel clumsy. The maps are just not built for navigating around.

You get thrown into the game not knowing what is happening, and then you realise it's online PvP only and random other players are thrown in (no pre-game summary of who's on each team).

Default keybinding with special weapons is confusing and not accessible. At least have a way to hover over the specials so you can find out what they do.

When there's a target of 50 kills but the timed PvP battles end too soon after just 10.
I had some network issues and lag, but that never killed my game. Rejoining the game was quick.

I love the mech idea but found the interface pretty horrible and not up to today's standards.
Some fonts are tiny, some fonts and buttons are huge. It just looks unpolished. 
Some help text doesn't even fit into the bounding box and there's no way to change the interface.

Uninstalled it after 4 matches.

author: {'steamid': '76561198084964281', 'num_games_owned': 224, 'num_reviews': 27, 'playtime_forever': 134, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 134, 'last_played': 1588553869}
review:
I had multiple issues in my short time, some technical, some personal and preferential.
I think it takes way too long to load. Finding a match doesn't take too long, loading a match takes longer than I like but it's not as long as some other games I've played. But the loading from launch to the splash screen takes much longer than I think it should reasonably take.
Subpar English translation.
Contains loot boxes (complete no for me), premium version (undesirable but acceptable to myself), and daily rewards (undesirable solely due to what that USUALLY but doesn't always entail about the game, but acceptable).

Movement doesn't feel right. In order to turn your mech's body, you have to aim far enough in the direction you want to turn that your torso drags your legs until they point the way you want. I'm not sure if what direction your legs point in actually effects your movement speed in any way, so this might not have any mechanical impact.

Some of the gameplay ideas are decent enough, but it feels very lacking, despite releasing over a year and a half ago.
For example, there is no tutorial. However, this isn't too big of an issue, considering the controls are very easy to grasp.
I do have to commend the developers for doing more than the minimum with some gameplay features, such as when you spawn in your drop pod and land on or near an enemy that is on the spawn point, it doesn't just do damage to the enemies, but they also get knocked over and have to stand back up before taking actions. As annoying as this is to the person it happens to, it does give the defenders of the spawn point have an edge, meaning that while Point Capture mode matches can stalemate a LITTLE bit, it doesn't inherently become a steamroll by one side without some serious effort.


At the least, I can say that the gameplay wasn't very satisfying, even though it was mildly engaging, and it certainly couldn't hold my attention through the grind that's been hinted at.

review:
After few hours of gameplay:
1st) I found game under MMO category to which it does not belong even while authors describe it as "MMO-Action".
2nd) It does not look like I am playing against actual players, but against bots. Seeing 3 bots in same place bugged. Bot trying to capture area, but standing just next to it. Same names of "players" as I switch regions over course of the day.
3rd) Currency rewards for blueprints are way too low. You can be 1st and get twice as much as "others" and you are getting 120~200 per match. Blueprints for desirable weapons come from 2000 to 5000. For mechs they go from 10000 to 100000.
4th) Small amounts of premium currency can be earned by completing "quests" which is actually faster way to get Currency for Blueprints as boxes for premium currency have Coins inside too.

author: {'steamid': '76561198043059130', 'num_games_owned': 383, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 73, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 73, 'last_played': 1554762281}
review:
In its current state, the game is largely unfinished and needs quite a bit of love.

Cons:
Every piece of equipment is crafted, and then randomly assigned a quality modifier.  This means that making anything particularly expensive becomes a huge gamble on whether or not your resources are well-spent or wasted.

Additionally, there just really isn't much in the game that you can craft, yet.  Most people can't afford TItan-class mechs, and everyone has at least one type of Stormtrooper-class mech, which means team composition looks like 1 Scout *or* Destroyer, and the rest are the default Stormtrooper you start the game with.

Credits and other materials used in crafting trickle in unless you buy into Premium, which doubles the rate of the trickle from "almost nothing" to "still almost nothing."  Blueprints cost thousands of credits, earned at a rate of maybe 90/winning match, and far less for losing matches. 

My biggest complaint is that it rarely drops you into a match that's freshly starting, *or* the number of kills necessary to win a given match is completely random; I haven't been able to figure out which.

Finally, as an aside, the English version of the game reads like something that was run through multiple iterations of Google Translate.  As a polyglot and someone who was raised bilingual, I'd really like to take a look at the Spanish version of the game, to see if it's as bad, but there's no option to switch languages.

Pros:

It's pretty easy to get kills in combat.  Just follow one of your teammates around and avoid shooting them while you shoot whomever they shoot at.  You'll both start racking up kills, because individual players tend to panic when ganged up on.  It's a team game, and if you play it like one, you will probably win.

I typically enjoy 3D graphical games played in top-down 2.5D.

From the start, the game has you pick a side, and then halfway through the tutorial, you are forced to build and play with the "opposing side," because strict, binary, assigned factions at character creation don't make sense and would inevitably lead to one side being way more populated and overpowered than the other.

The game is fairly lightweight for something running 3D graphics.  I keep an eye on my processor, RAM, disk, and network usage by it while playing, and I think it says something that it doesn't cause the crashing issues that some games do when run alongside Firefox and other meaty web browsers.

5/10, game needs some major work and balancing, or it will die.  I can barely recommend it at this time, but only to say, keep an eye on it and see if it improves, if this is your thing.

review:
This Game Is Great. It is multiplayer, but I'm not really sure if I'm playing with actual people or bots. I think they are mostly bots.. I went on the steam charts page and it said there were only 3 people playing the game within the last 25 minutes. 

Still fun to play with the bots, considering that I thought they were real players for a while. Some of the bots are quite easy to kill and some others a quite hard to kill, this kind of represents how players are in most online games which makes it feel even more like you are playing with real people and plenty of bots spawn on each team!

The game mode you play when you enter a server is like the domination mode from COD. you walk around killing other players and capture the points, so not much to say on that except there is only one mode you can play right now.

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=1247841397

The game does get 60 fps for me, but it still feels like I'm playing it al like 30 and when I start shooting at people it feels like even less. When there are more than 4 people on the screen shooting the fps goes down to 15. This is on low settings with a 1060 and i5-4430 @ 3GHz. Pretty un-optimized if you ask me. Don't get me wrong though you can still have fun on the game even with low fps like that, maybe don't spend ¬£6 if you don't have a 1050ti minimum I would say considering that I get 15 fps when in a fight with more than 4 people.

The controls are pretty nice and you can re-map them in the setting to fit how you play the game. When you get in-game you can definitely feel how controlling your character may seem difficult, but you do kind of get used to how it works. Also when you spawn in your tech has a limited amount of sprinting, in most games this regens. I'm not sure if its a bug, buy it would be nice if in this game the stamina would reset as well. It seems like most of the time I'm walking around slowly because I have run out of stamina.

In conclusion, this game isn't very easy to run, your character is not very easy to control and you don't regen stamina. I would love for some of these things to be fixed, so everyone playing can have more fun. Also, I saw that they are making a tech customization thing, that could be pretty cool.

7 cp out of 11 cp

review:
Techwars Online 2 is a pretty good game for those who like capture the flag style play. It's not really the type of game that I play usually, but I enjoyed it. I found the controls to be a little bit clunky for my taste, but it could be that I am just not used to the combination of the way the screen moves with the location of the mouse crosshairs. I found that I was having a hard time dialing in on a target when I needed to. Again, could just be me and my inexperience with this style of game. 

I did find the graphics to be less than what I expected. In the preview of the game it notes that everything is destructable, but I found that buildings did not fall and other objects were not destroyed the way I was led to believe from the preview. In addition, I found that the mech would walk through some things, and not others. Seemed a little buggy in the collision of objects.

Gameplay is pretty good. I found myself coming back to play several times. I think the mechanics of the game could be refined, and that the mechs move a little slow for the objectives that need to be met. Instructions on the game could also be a bit clearer.

The first time I played, I had a rectangular portion of my screen that was black, and I couldn't see my special manuvers or weapons. Not surre if this was a bug, or an overlay that was acting up. Almost looked like it was supposed to be a chat window. I do think that being able to chat with your team would make this a better game by far, as it would enable you to have more strategy and planning. It would also be nice to be able to create a team with friends. I did not see that option.

Overall, I think this is a great game and would recommend it to those who like this style of gameplay. Althoug it is not my favorite gaming genre, I still enjoy the gameplay.

So I first want to thank Argus gaming again for providing more keys so I could test this game with more then just myself, so me at 5 other people (subscribers) went in and tried the game on a bigger scale!

So starting out this game is far more fun social then it ever will be solo, just running around shooting mechs is great but was actually fun with a groupe of people...

Normally again I would do a list of pros and cons... but this game is so unfinished I can't even start due to how many "features" are missing, from the lack of lobbies, to the horrible lag (200 ms ping) which acted like 3 times or more then what it showed... you could not aim accurately under the latency provided on the game. as well as since there are still no one showing up to play with us we had the run of the place.

Since it is alpha there are to be bugs but all in all we had fun, some of the issues was aiming damage registering, not knowing if we hit or not, and how unbalanced the game it... and by unbalanced we are talking about maps are unbalanced weapons are unbalanced mechs are unbalanced, laser was unlimited ammo and more op then anything else, at least as far as we could tell under the situation. and the maps the locations you have to claim (like capture the point) are so misplaced one team has a distance advantage to some more points then the other... but not only that if one team claims a lead in the beginning and gets the points... you CANNOT come back from it. the domination becomes one sided as you can spawn from any point you control allowing you to take and SPAWN CAMP the other team to death.

End statement

This game could be fun but still needs a LOT of work to even be functional enough to sell, and this should not be sold yet until that point.
